articles.headline: Unease in Hawaii’s Cornfields
articles.snippet: With the collapse of the sugar and pineapple industries, seeds have become the state’s leading agricultural commodity, but residents are concerned.
articles.abstract: With the collapse of the sugar and pineapple industries, seeds have become the state’s leading agricultural commodity, but residents are concerned.
articles.lead_paragraph: WAIMEA, Hawaii — The balmy tropical isles here seem worlds apart from the expansive cornfields of the Midwest, but Hawaii has become the latest battleground in the fight over genetically modified crops.

articles.headline: Default Threat Generates Fear Around Globe
articles.snippet: Five years after a financial crisis in the United States helped spread a deep global recession, much of the world again fears collateral damage.
articles.abstract: Five years after a financial crisis in the United States helped spread a deep global recession, much of the world again fears collateral damage.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The bitter fiscal stalemate in Washington is producing nervous ripples from London to Bali, with increasing anxiety that the United States might actually default on a portion of its government debt, set off global financial troubles and undercut fragile economic recoveries in many countries.

articles.headline: Gates’s Future Fuels Speculation as Microsoft Seeks New Chief
articles.snippet: As Microsoft prepares to name a new chief executive and plot a course out of its funk, the role of Bill Gates has been a source of wide fascination.
articles.abstract: As Microsoft prepares to name a new chief executive and plot a course out of its funk, the role of Bill Gates has been a source of wide fascination.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — There’s a question being whispered around Microsoft’s sprawling suburban campus: What will Bill Gates do?

articles.headline: Billions in Debt, Detroit Faces Millions in Bills for Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: Even as it wrestles with $18 billion in debt, the city has been charged more than $19.1 million by the firms and individuals hired to sort through the bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: Even as it wrestles with $18 billion in debt, the city has been charged more than $19.1 million by the firms and individuals hired to sort through the bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — This city is learning that it is expensive to go broke.

articles.headline: Worsening Debt Crisis Threatens Puerto Rico
articles.snippet: Mired in debt, Puerto Rico has been effectively shut out of the bond market and is financing its operations with bank credit and other short-term measures.
articles.abstract: Mired in debt, Puerto Rico has been effectively shut out of the bond market and is financing its operations with bank credit and other short-term measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: While Detroit has preoccupied Americans with its record-breaking municipal bankruptcy, another public finance crisis on a potentially greater scale has been developing off most Americans’ radar screens, in Puerto Rico.

articles.headline: Little Fear on Wall St. of Default, at Moment
articles.snippet: The relative calm on Wall Street is worrying some investors, who fear the markets will not signal to politicians the true danger of hitting the debt ceiling until it is too late.
articles.abstract: The relative calm on Wall Street is worrying some investors, who fear the markets will not signal to politicians the true danger of hitting the debt ceiling until it is too late.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street is showing few signs so far that it is fearing the financial panic it has been predicting should the government default on its debt.

articles.headline: No Way U.S. Would Allow Debt Default? Don’t Bet on It
articles.snippet: The more Wall Street is convinced that Washington will act rationally and raise the debt ceiling, the less pressure there will be on lawmakers.
articles.abstract: The more Wall Street is convinced that Washington will act rationally and raise the debt ceiling, the less pressure there will be on lawmakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: “The United States government is not going to default, ever.”

articles.headline: Veto Halts Bill for Jury Duty by Noncitizens in California
articles.snippet: After signing into law numerous measures praised by immigrants’ rights groups, Gov. Jerry Brown denied noncitizens what he called a “responsibility of citizenship.”
articles.abstract: After signing into law numerous measures praised by immigrants’ rights groups, Gov. Jerry Brown denied noncitizens what he called a “responsibility of citizenship.”
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Breaking with Democrats in the State Legislature, Gov. Jerry Brown vetoed a bill on Monday that would have made California the first state to allow immigrants who are not citizens to serve on juries, saying that the responsibility should come only with citizenship.

articles.headline: A G.O.P. Moderate in the Middle ... of a Jam
articles.snippet: Defying the party line, Representative Charlie Dent, Republican of Pennsylvania, is urging Speaker John A. Boehner to allow a vote on a budget bill without conditions.
articles.abstract: Defying the party line, Representative Charlie Dent, Republican of Pennsylvania, is urging Speaker John A. Boehner to allow a vote on a budget bill without conditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a moderate House Republican, Representative Charlie Dent of Pennsylvania by definition typically finds himself somewhere near the middle when the majority of his colleagues veer well to the right.

articles.headline: For Shoppers, Next Level of Instant Gratification
articles.snippet: New shopping services will allow consumers to instantly buy items they see on television, in magazines and even in their refrigerators.
articles.abstract: New shopping services will allow consumers to instantly buy items they see on television, in magazines and even in their refrigerators.
articles.lead_paragraph: All the world’s a shopping cart.

articles.headline: To Lift Hong Kong Park, Disney Deploys Iron Man
articles.snippet: An Iron Man-themed thrill ride, photo pavilion and shopping area will open at Hong Kong Disneyland in late 2016.
articles.abstract: An Iron Man-themed thrill ride, photo pavilion and shopping area will open at Hong Kong Disneyland in late 2016.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Iron Man has proved his might at the Chinese box office. Now Disney is betting that the Marvel superhero has enough muscle to complete a turnaround at its underperforming theme park here — a task of crucial importance as the company hurtles toward the opening of a mega-resort in Shanghai.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: European Lawmakers Reject Tight Restrictions on E-Cigarettes
articles.snippet: The European Parliament, in a move favored by users and producers of electronic cigarettes, voted against regulating the products as medical devices.
articles.abstract: The European Parliament, in a move favored by users and producers of electronic cigarettes, voted against regulating the products as medical devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: STRASBOURG, France — The European Parliament on Tuesday scrapped proposals by health officials that electronic cigarettes be tightly regulated as medical devices, setting the stage for a debate in the United States over the extent of regulation.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Matt Richtel
